description.narrative: The project is expected to: i) Support Lending and Growth in the East African Market: Equity Bank has a wide distribution network in East Africa with subsidiaries in Uganda and South Sudan, offering financial services to the large unbanked population. The Project will support the Banks continued growth ultimately contributing to renewed economic activity in East Africa. (ii) Increased Access to Finance for SMEs: SME''s are a key growth sector for EBL. IFC will assist with SME development beyond financing to include advisory services for key aspects of its SME operations including lending to the agricultural sector and women entrepreneurs. The expected improvement in access to finance for SMEs will help to generate employment at the grass roots level and further facilitate regional trade which is expected to grow rapidly following the economic integration of the East African Community. (iii) Support regional Expansion and integration IFC''s engagement with EBL will its regional expansion strategy and contribute to increased competition and service in the regional banking sector. This will strengthen the regional economy and contribute to the success of the newly created economic community. (iv) Increased Financial Inclusion at the bottom of the pyramid Equity Banks has a clear focus and commitment to increasing financial inclusion at the bottom of the pyramid through new and innovative products and services. IFCs investment will support the Banks growth strategy and allow it to reach even more customers at the bottom of the pyramid.

The proposed engagement with Equity Bank Limited (EBL or the Bank) is aligned to IFCs strategy for the East African financial sector. The Project consists of a US$100 million senior loan to EBL, to help the Bank grow its lending to Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME), women entrepreneurs and the agricultural sector, and to support its regional expansion in East Africa. EBL is a commercial bank providing inclusive financial services with a specific focus on the underserved populations in Kenya, Uganda and South Sudan, with a customer base of 6.3 million majority of them small savers and an asset base of close to US$ 2 billion as of June 30, 2011.In addition to traditional brick and mortar outlets the bank has rolled out multiple delivery channels including ATMs, cash back services and POS to increase access to financial services. The bank recently rolled out mobile banking and agency banking which will take banking services to the remote areas and further increase access.
